ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Field trips were great! The more trips, the better we learned the material. It was great to do non-leaf ID after the leaves had fallen. I also appreciated the teacher and TA making sure they reminded people not to shout out the answer too quickly.
I would loved to have taken a field trip or two on the course.

The TA for this course, Henry Glick, was incredible. He was the best TA I've ever had in a university course. He was extremely dedicated to ensuring we learned and understood all the material.The course was excellent, but I would recommend having it meet for 3 hours M and W, but just for the first half of the semester, so the course can run while leaves are still on the trees.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Field trips! They were numerous (almost every week), useful and very varied. We saw a large array of ecosystems in some great sites and it truly is the best way to learn taxonomy. Very satisfying to see how you become more and more confident week after week and are able to take in an increasing amount of information.Also, kudos to Henry Glick for being the most amazing, dedicated and knowledgeable taxonomy TA of all time.
The field trips. This is stuff you can't learn from a textbook/lecture.
The depth of the professor's knowledge and his awesome stories.
The field trips were excellent and greatly enhanced my learning.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Powerpoints. Most of the material was produced by a former post-doc (Dr. Phillip Marshall) and is not actually tailored to what Professor Camp expects us to know. There is too much information and it's hard to know what we should learn and what we should discard. It would be nice if the slides were given an update next year.
Better/easier access to the in-class presentations.
None except for the suggested schedule improvement above.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Excellent balance between lectures and field trips. Could even scrap the lecture from the dean! Eric from the greenhouse would probably a better greenhouse guide too.
Not applicable.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I think every Master of Forestry student should know his or her trees. Calling yourself a land manager or a forest ecologist if you don't is preposterous. You owe it to both the land and the people you'll be working for to be able to understand an ecosystem and name its parts.

Essential knowledge for anyone not having good grasp of the local trees and shrubs. I was very surprised that other forestry students were not in this class. I hope they can hold their own in the coming semesters when tree ID is needed...
This course is crucial for my overall program as it is critical material for anyone studying forests.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am an international student and will probably not be working in New England after I graduate, so I've often been told that taking this class was a waste of my time. I don't agree about that. Coming from another part of the world, you find yourself at a disadvantage compared to people who grew up here and are familiar with local ecosystems. Plus if you don't know what concrete is, you'll have a hard time learning about architecture... I would feel bad taking decisions as a forestry professional without knowing my portfolio of species.
To familiarize myself with the trees and shrubs that we will be working with for the next two years.

In order to understand forests, you have to know which trees are present and how they relate to each other. Therefore, I felt like it was essential for me to have a thorough understanding of dendrology to be able to successfully work in the field.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I now feel as confident as any (and more confident than many) other forestry student while walking in a forest, and I am sure that this will prove a huge gain of time for Mark Ashton's silviculture class. Most of this knowledge is applicable everywhere: you learn how to look at plants more than a list of names. I now have a mental toolbox that I can use in any situation.
Yes.
Yes, absolutely.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Not applicable.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Start your tree ID cards/guide early on and just keep adding to it. Actually, making a guide or something you could bring into the field and add to (instead of taking notes and then adding later) would be very useful.
If you have any interest in trees and forests, you should definitely take this class. It is an incredibly enjoyable way to master the taxonomy of New England forests.
